title: The Long Way Home

setting.environment: Stone cottages with thatched roofs, misty green hills, crowded train stations with steam locomotives, muddy trenches

characters.name: Thomas
characters.description: Young Irish soldier in his early 20s. Dark curly hair, weathered face with kind eyes, wearing a British Army uniform. Has a quiet strength about him.

characters.name: Mary
characters.description: Thomas's wife, late teens to early 20s. Auburn red hair, freckles across her nose, bright hopeful eyes. Wears simple rural dresses typical of 1940s Ireland. Becomes visibly pregnant by the final act.

characters.name: The Child
characters.description: Newborn baby wrapped in a white knitted blanket. Only appears in the final scene.

tone.mood: Bittersweet and melancholic with hopeful undertones that build toward an emotional resolution
tone.colour_palette: Desaturated greens and greys for war scenes, warm amber and soft golden tones for home and reunion scenes
tone.visual_style: Cinematic 35mm film aesthetic with natural film grain. Mix of intimate handheld close-ups and sweeping wide establishing shots. Shallow depth of field for emotional moments.

key_moments.description: Thomas writing a letter by candlelight in a muddy trench at night, rain falling outside
Intercut between Thomas marching with his regiment and Mary reading his letter by the cottage window
Warm, golden flashback to their wedding day - dancing outside the cottage, genuine joy and laughter
Intense battle scenes, rain and mud, Thomas protecting the letter inside his jacket
Mary alone and visibly pregnant, standing at the window watching rain fall, touching her belly
Train arriving at the station, steam clearing dramatically, Thomas and Mary's emotional reunion on the platform
Thomas holding their newborn baby, Mary beside him, their cottage in the background as the sun sets

style_references: 1917 (2019) - for continuous motion and immersive war sequences
Atonement (2007) - for the library/reunion scene lighting and period atmosphere
Band of Brothers - for authentic period military detail
Brooklyn (2015) - for the soft, romantic Irish scenes
additional_notes: The song builds from quiet, reflective verses to an emotional climax at the final chorus. The visual intensity should match this arc - starting subdued and building to the powerful reunion. Avoid anything that feels too modern or digital. Keep it grounded, real, and emotionally authentic. The love story is the heart of it - the war is the obstacle, not the focus.
